property.name: _windowProperties
property.value: {bounds={353, 91, 1038, 727}, maximized=false}

property.name: text
property.value:
There are 3 main steps in setting up authentication: 1) Turning on GraphDB security 2) Configuring GraphDB's REST server for HTTPS 3) Managing the HTTPS certificate 4) Select appropriate accessor parameters: protocol = https and authenticate = true
When these have been accomplished the model below should execute without error.

property.name: text
property.value:
1) Turning on graphDB security
Log on to GraphDB's control panel and go to Setup/Users and Access. The security slider in the upper right hand corner defaults to "off". Switch it to on, and log back in with the admin username/password (defaults to "admin" and "root"). For more information, check out http://graphdb.ontotext.com/documentation/8.5/free/access-rights-and-security.html.

property.name: text
property.value:
2) Configuring GraphDB's REST server for HTTPS
GraphDB's authentication modes are detailed at http://graphdb.ontotext.com/documentation/standard/authentication.html. These accessors use the Basic Authentication mode at the bottom of the page, where username and password are sent as a header. As such a header is sent in plain text over http, we must enable https (note other authentication modes also require https to avoid replay attacks). Note the documentation is incorrect. Username password combos are base64 encodings of strings of the form <username>:<password>, not of the form <username>/<password>.
Steps for turning on encryption are given at http://graphdb.ontotext.com/documentation/standard/encryption.html. The key point is "GraphDB runs on [sic] embedded Tomcat server" which can be indirectly configured through a graphdb.properties file. Documentation on this properties file is at http://graphdb.ontotext.com/documentation/free/configuring-graphdb.html. Crucialy, properties of the relevant Tomcat Connector attribute can be set by setting a value for a graphDB attribute "graphdb.connector." + the relevant Tomcat Connector attribute.
The graphdb.properties file should have the name "graphdb.properties" and be located in the distribution under conf/graphdb.properties. On my Mac, the path is ~/Library/ApplicationSupport/GraphDB/conf/graphdb.properties. An example graphdb.properties is in this SemanticRepository demo directory. To use the example you will have to replace the section <INSERT YOUR PATH TO KEYSTORE HERE!> with the actual path to your keystore (more on this later)
We now refer to the apache Tomcat documenation on how to set a Tomcat server's attributes for encryption. See https://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-7.0-doc/ssl-howto.html#Edit_the_Tomcat_Configuration_File, but be warned in my experience variables like ${user.home} are not correctly passed through graphdb.connector. to the Tomcat configuration.

property.name: text
property.value:
3) Managing the HTTPS certificate
Finally, we must generate a certificate for GraphDB, link the certificate to the configuration in section (2), and inform the swarmlet host's keystore to trust the certificate if it is self-signed (as in these instructions). If a certificate is obtained from a certificate authority some of these instructions may likely be skipable.
First, generate a self signed certificate. See https://www.sslshopper.com/article-most-common-java-keytool-keystore-commands.html. Run:
$keytool -genkey -keyalg RSA -alias selfsigned -keystore keystore.jks -storepass changeit -validity 360 -keysize 2048
to generate a keystore named "keystore.jks" with the password "changeit". Note this password is consistent with the example graphdb.properties file and you'll have to change the file if you change the password. IMPORTANT! Be sure to correctly enter the server name "localhost" in response to keytoolâ€™s first prompt (assuming that is you are running on localhost) when it asks "What is your first and last name?" Otherwise this won't work.
Next, you'll need to export the public key certificate from keystore.jks. See https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/security/toolsign/step5.html. Run:
$keytool -export -keystore keystore.jks -alias selfsigned -file selfsigned.cer
to generate the file selfsigned.cer. It is important to remember the alias "selfsigned" (incidentally the same name as the file, but it doesn't have to be) because we will use it to add or remove the certificate from our swarmlet host's keystore. If you are running on the Nashron host, as I am for these instructions, your keystore will be located at JAVA_HOME/JRE/lib/security/cacerts. If you don't know where JAVA_HOME is on your machine, run
$/usr/libexec/java_home -v 1.8
For me this is: /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_121.jdk/Contents/Home/jre/lib/security/cacerts. For more information see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8980364/how-do-i-find-out-what-keystore-my-jvm-is-using.
Finally, we add the self-signed certificate to the swarmlet host's keystore. See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2893819/accept-servers-self-signed-ssl-certificate-in-java-client. Run:
sudo keytool -import -v -trustcacerts -alias selfsigned -file selfsigned.cer -keystore <INSERT PATH TO YOUR HOST KEYSTORE> -keypass changeit -storepass changeit
Again, for me I replace <INSERT PATH TO YOUR HOST KEYSTORE> with /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_121.jdk/Contents/Home/jre/lib/security/cacerts.
That's it! Now your accessors should be able to connect to GraphDB over https.
If something went wrong in this process and you want to remove a certificate from your host's keystore. See https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19798-01/821-1751/ghleq/index.html Run:
sudo keytool -delete -alias selfsigned -keystore <INSERT PATH TO YOUR HOST KEYSTORE> -storepass changeit
This is where the alias is important. Be sure not to remove the wrong certificate!

entity.name: StringConst

property.name: value
property.value: SELECT * WHERE {?s ?p ?o} LIMIT 10

entity.doc: Create a constant sequence with a string value.

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor

property.name: description
property.value: Display data using util.inspect() to render a more human-readable form. Any data accepted by util.inspect() can be displayed. The title may be used by the host to label the output in some way, either by labeling a display window or prepending the printed text with the title. The resulting text is passed through to the output in case a model wishes to ensure that the image has been displayed before something else happens or the model wishes to use the rendered text in some way.

property.name: author
property.value: Edward A. Lee

property.name: input (port)
property.value: The text to display.

property.name: output (port)
property.value: The text to display.

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor

property.name: description
property.value:
Perform a SPARQL query on a semantic repository such as GraphDB.

SPARQL is a W3C standard for querying semantic repositories, playing an analogous role to SQL with respect to relational databases. Semantic repositories fall within the domain of knowledge representation in AI and typically are implemented as a triplestore: entries in the repository have the form "subject", "predicate", "object" eg. "An Apple" "IsA" "Fruit"

An example SPARQL query to get a list of up to 100 triples in the repository:

select * where { ?s ?p ?o . } limit 100

Documentation for SPARQL and the SPARQL Protocol can be found at https://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-sparql-query/

Information on GraphDB can be found at http://graphdb.ontotext.com/

SPARQL is also a protocol for communicating with RDF databases Upon receiving a query input, this accessor performs an http GET to the specified server and port with the querystring "query" set to the query input. The JSON response from the semantic repository (if any) is sent to the response output. Depending on the query type, the response will be JSON "sparql-results" or "rdf+json"

This accessor does not block waiting for the response, but if any additional query input is received before a pending request has received a response or timed out, then the new request will be queued and sent out only after the pending request has completed. This strategy ensures that outputs are produced in the same order as the input requests.

property.name: author
property.value: Matt Weber

property.name: version
property.value: $$Id: SemanticRepository.js 1725 2017-05-19 22:59:11Z cxh $$

property.name: query (port)
property.value: The SPARQL query to be sent to the semantic repository. Types of queries yielding a response are: SELECT, CONSTRUCT, ASK, and DESCRIBE

property.name: response (port)
property.value: An object containing the raw response from the service conforming to the SPARQL protocol. If the query type was SELECT or ASK the response will be JSON "sparql-results". If the query type was CONSTRUCT or DESCRIBE the response will be "rdf+json".

property.name: protocol (parameter)
property.value: Either http or https.

property.name: host (parameter)
property.value: The URL for the semantic repository.

property.name: port (parameter)
property.value: The port for the semantic repository.

property.name: repositoryName (parameter)
property.value: The name of the particular repository on the host.

property.name: authenticate (parameter)
property.value: If true, enable authentication to an access controlled semantic repository by sending username and password with request. If false, username and password information will not be sent. An error will occur if the http protocol is selected with a true authenticate setting to avoid sending username/password information in plain text.

property.name: username (parameter)
property.value: A username for an access controlled semantic repository.

property.name: password (parameter)
property.value: A password for an access controlled semantic repository.

property.name: timeout (parameter)
property.value: The amount of time (in milliseconds) to wait for a response before triggering a null response and an error. This defaults to 20000.

property.name: _windowProperties
property.value: {bounds={765, 212, 499, 208}, maximized=false}

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor

property.name: description
property.value: Display data using util.inspect() to render a more human-readable form. Any data accepted by util.inspect() can be displayed. The title may be used by the host to label the output in some way, either by labeling a display window or prepending the printed text with the title. The resulting text is passed through to the output in case a model wishes to ensure that the image has been displayed before something else happens or the model wishes to use the rendered text in some way.

property.name: author
property.value: Edward A. Lee

property.name: input (port)
property.value: The text to display.

property.name: output (port)
property.value: The text to display.

entity.name: Atomic Delete Then Insert

property.name: value
property.value: DELETE { <http://ptolemy.berkeley.edu/a> <http://ptolemy.berkeley.edu/b> <http://ptolemy.berkeley.edu/c> .} INSERT { <http://ptolemy.berkeley.edu/a> <http://ptolemy.berkeley.edu/b> <http://ptolemy.berkeley.edu/c> .} WHERE {}

entity.doc: Create a constant sequence with a string value.

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor

property.name: description
property.value:
Perform a SPARQL update on a semantic repository such as GraphDB.

SPARQL is a W3C standard for querying semantic repositories, playing an analogous role to SQL with respect to relational databases. Semantic repositories fall within the domain of knowledge representation in AI and typically are implemented as a triplestore: entries in the repository have the form "subject", "predicate", "object" eg. "An Apple" "IsA" "Fruit"

An example SPARQL update to add a triple to the repository:

INSERT DATA { http://ptolemy.berkeley.edu/a http://ptolemy.berkeley.edu/b http://ptolemy.berkeley.edu/c . }

Documentation for SPARQL and the SPARQL Protocol 1.1 introducing updates can be found at https://www.w3.org/TR/sparql11-query/

Information on GraphDB can be found at http://graphdb.ontotext.com/

SPARQL is also a protocol for communicating with RDF databases Upon receiving an update input, this accessor performs an http POST to the specified server and port with the body set to the update input. The http status code is produced on the output with a 204 response from the server indicating success. If a different status code is received, this accessor throws an error. Note that an INSERT that inserts data already in the repository or a DELETE that removes data already absent from the repository is treated by the respository as a successful update.

This accessor does not block waiting for the response, but if any additional update input is received before a pending request has received a response or timed out, then the new request will be queued and sent out only after the pending request has completed. This strategy ensures that outputs are produced in the same order as the input requests.

property.name: author
property.value: Matt Weber

property.name: version
property.value: $$Id: SemanticRepository.js 1725 2017-05-19 22:59:11Z cxh $$

property.name: update (port)
property.value: The update to be sent to the semantic repository. Types of SPARQL updates are: INSERT and DELETE, but raw ontology data is accepted too with appropriate format.

property.name: status (port)
property.value: The status code of the http POST to the Semantic Repository. A 204 code indicates success.

property.name: format (parameter)
property.value: The format of data sent to the ontology. Currently only supports data types from http://docs.rdf4j.org/rest-api/#_content_types.

property.name: host (parameter)
property.value: The URL for the semantic repository.

property.name: port (parameter)
property.value: The port for the semantic repository.

property.name: repositoryName (parameter)
property.value: The name of the particular repository on the host.

property.name: authenticate (parameter)
property.value: If true, enable authentication to an access controlled semantic repository by sending username and password with request. If false, username and password information will not be sent. An error will occur if the http protocol is selected with a true authenticate setting to avoid sending username/password information in plain text.

property.name: username (parameter)
property.value: A username for an access controlled semantic repository.

property.name: password (parameter)
property.value: A password for an access controlled semantic repository.

property.name: timeout (parameter)
property.value: The amount of time (in milliseconds) to wait for a response before triggering a null response and an error. This defaults to 20000.
